Finally, based on (3), x^0subscript^𝑥0\widehat{x}_{0} could be obtained. We will refer to this scheme as linear fusion with suboptimal coefficients (LFSC) in the following. Note that the computation and I/O complexity of LFSC is manageable since each parameter in 𝒫ksubscript𝒫𝑘\mathcal{P}_{k} is a vector or a scalar, and the detailed computational complexity is given in Table I. It can be observed the overall complexity of LFSC is significantly reduced compared to CBP.

We will refer to this scheme as linear fusion with constant coefficients (LFCC) in the following. The complexity of LFCC is also given in Table I which is much lower than that of LFSC. Note that LFCC can be implemented by the FD feedforward architecture [2], where the CU only needs to take the weighted sum of local detection results and does not require any additional intermediate results or processing.

The following lemma gives the stochastic equivalents for the functions in Table II.

The proof relies on Gaussian tools [34, 35, 36, 16, 37], which consist of the integration by parts formula [35, Eq. (17)] and the Poincaré-Nash inequality [35, Eq. (18)]. According to the Poincaré–Nash inequality, the variance of functions defined in Table II can be proved of order 𝒪​(1)𝒪1{\mathcal{O}}(1) (See [32, Lemma 9] for the case of ϝksubscriptitalic-ϝ𝑘\digamma_{k} and the proof of other functions are similar).
